title: Rawal Commission Report on Public Land Encroachment in Kathmandu
description:
The case revolves around the findings of the 'High Level Commission on Government and Public Land Inquiry and Conservation', popularly known as the Rawal Commission. Formed on December 31, 1992, by the government of then-Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala and chaired by former secretary Ram Bahadur Rawal, the commission was tasked with investigating the illegal occupation of public and government land in Kathmandu.

After a two-year investigation, the commission submitted its report around 1994. It revealed that a total of 1,859 ropani and 14 anna of public and government-owned land had been illegally encroached upon by approximately 5,000 individuals and organizations. The report identified encroachments in valuable urban areas such as Chabahil, Bouddha, Thapathali, and Baneshwor, affecting public paths, ponds, streams, and temple lands.

Despite its comprehensive findings, the report was effectively shelved by successive governments for nearly 25 years. Officials have suggested this inaction was due to the involvement of influential and high-ranking individuals. On May 26, 2010, the Supreme Court of Nepal, responding to a writ petition by advocate Prakash Mani Sharma, issued a directive ordering the government to implement the report's recommendations with high priority, but significant action was not taken.

The full 1,350-page report remained confidential until the Centre for Investigative Journalism-Nepal (CIJ-Nepal) obtained it through a Right to Information (RTI) request and published a detailed exposé on May 2, 2019. This publication brought the issue back into the public discourse.

More recently, the Kathmandu Metropolitan City (KMC), under Mayor Balendra Shah, has launched a campaign to reclaim the encroached lands, citing the Rawal Commission's report as a primary basis for its actions. The estimated market value of the encroached land is approximately NPR 200 billion.
unverified_info:
While the Rawal Commission report is extensive, a complete and consolidated public list of all ~5,000 implicated individuals and organizations is not readily available in a single document. The Centre for Investigative Journalism-Nepal has published a searchable database with names from the report, but not the complete list in one place.

The specific identities of the 'powerful and high-ranking individuals' who allegedly obstructed the implementation of the report for over two decades have not been officially disclosed or investigated.

The exact date in 1994 when the commission submitted its final report is not specified in the source materials, though it is consistently cited as being after a two-year investigation.
key_allegations: Illegal encroachment on 1,859 ropani and 14 anna of public and government land in Kathmandu by approximately 5,000 individuals and organizations.
Systematic failure and deliberate inaction by successive governments of Nepal to implement the findings of the 1994 Rawal Commission report for over two decades.
Obstruction of justice by influential and politically connected individuals implicated in the land grabbing.
Non-compliance with a 2010 Supreme Court order to implement the commission's report.

timeline.title: Rawal Commission Formed
timeline.description: The government led by Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala formed the 'High Level Commission on Government and Public Land Inquiry and Conservation' under the chairmanship of former secretary Ram Bahadur Rawal.

timeline.title: Commission Submits Report
timeline.description: After a two-year investigation, the Rawal Commission submitted its report identifying 1,859 ropani of encroached public land. The report was subsequently shelved by the government.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Orders Implementation
timeline.description: In response to a writ petition, the Supreme Court of Nepal issued a directive ordering the Government of Nepal to implement the recommendations of the Rawal Commission report with high priority.

timeline.title: RTI Application Filed for Report
timeline.description: The Centre for Investigative Journalism-Nepal (CIJ-Nepal) filed a Right to Information (RTI) application to obtain the full Rawal Commission report.

timeline.title: CIJ-Nepal Publishes Findings
timeline.description: CIJ-Nepal published an investigative story based on the Rawal Commission report, making its detailed findings public for the first time.

sources.title: 5,000 individuals have grabbed 1,800 ropani public land in Kathmandu
sources.description: A detailed investigative report by the Centre for Investigative Journalism-Nepal (published May 2, 2019) that first publicized the findings of the Rawal Commission report after obtaining it via an RTI request. It outlines the commission's formation, total encroached land, and specific examples.

sources.title: काठमाडौंमा १९ सय रोपनी सरकारी जग्गा अतिक्रमण, ۵ हजार जनाको सूचीसहितको प्रतिवेदन गायब (Nepali)
sources.description: The original Nepali language version of the CIJ-Nepal investigation (published May 2, 2019). It confirms the commission's formation date in the Nepali calendar (2049 Poush 16) and contains a link to a searchable database of encroachers named in the report.

sources.title: KMC to reclaim 1,859 ropani of encroached public land: Mayor Shah
sources.description: A news report from The Himalayan Times detailing the initiative by Kathmandu Mayor Balendra Shah to reclaim the 1,859 ropani of land based on the Rawal Commission's report. It also states the estimated value of the land at Rs 200 billion. (Note: The article date's year is likely a typo).

sources.title: Encroached public spaces are turning into parks
sources.description: A follow-up report by CIJ-Nepal (published January 14, 2020) that references the 1994 Rawal Commission report and discusses the broader context of reclaiming public land in Kathmandu.
